text:
So welcome everyone to
AA228V CS238V, Validation

of Safety-Critical Systems. If you're here for that class,
you're in the right spot. If you're here from a different
class, you're in the wrong spot.

And we promise not to
judge if you get up and leave now if you're
in the wrong spot. That was definitely
one of my biggest fears

as a student on the
first day of class. So my name is Sydney Katz. I'll be the primary
instructor for this course

along with a super
awesome teaching team. And we'll all introduce
ourselves shortly.

But first I want to
jump in by just saying, so this is actually the
first quarter-long full class

that I've ever taught. And I'm really excited about it. And so I thought long
and hard about what

the first slide of the first
lecture of the first class that I ever teach should be.
And here's what I came up with. Yay! [LAUGHTER]

So yay, for a couple of reasons. One, I'm just super excited
to have this opportunity. I think throughout my
entire academic journey,

I've always really loved
teaching and helping students understand concepts. And so I'm just really excited
to have this opportunity.

And also yay, because I'm
excited about the particular class that we're
teaching here, which

is validation of
safety-critical systems. So I think this is actually
one of the first classes

of its kind. It's a new class, as
you probably know. And, I think, a
lot of the skills

that you'll take
away from this class are going to be extremely
useful and valuable, whether you go into industry or academia in
a whole wide variety of domains.

So I'm just really
excited to share all of that knowledge
and skills with you. So yay.

All right. So with that, I'm
going to jump in now and talk a little bit
about the textbook

that we're going to
use for this class. So the textbook is called
Algorithms for Validation.

It was co-authored by
myself, Mykel Kochenderfer, who's one of the co-instructors
for this course, Anthony

Corso, and Robert Moss. And so this textbook is
actually the third textbook

in a series of textbooks. They're all algorithms books. So if you've taken any
of Mykel's other classes,

such as AA222, or maybe last
quarter, you took AA228, you might have used one of
these textbooks in the past.

And the way I see
these textbooks fitting together is like this. So in the first two
textbooks, we design steps.

So we design
decision-making systems. We optimize them. And then once we're
done with that,

we come over to this
textbook or to this class, and we check if what we
designed actually works.

So we check if it does what
we intended for it to do. But ideally, we're
going to find out

in a controlled and
safe environment, such as a simulation instead
of in the real world,

unlike these people.  So the one on the
right is actually me.

[LAUGHTER] I can tell you that was from
when I was an undergrad, so I hadn't taken any
validation classes yet.

I didn't know what I was doing. So there was no
validation involved. I just started
spinning around a bat

and didn't really know how
dizzy that would make me. Definitely had no chance
of hitting that pi√±ata.

So those were some fun systems. But in this class,
we're mostly going to be focused on
decision-making systems

and specifically decision-making
systems that operate over time. So this could be something like
a robot, an autonomous vehicle,

an autonomous aircraft, maybe
a financial system, or a health care system.

And in this class,
we're just going to wrap that all into
this one component that we call the system.

So in other classes,
you may have learned to design, intelligent
decision-making systems like this. In this class, we're
going to assume

we already have that system. And now we want to check if it
does what we wanted it to do.

And to do that, we have to
give it some specification. So we need to write down
something that tells us

what it is we actually
wanted the system to do when we
designed it, and what do we want it to do when we
deploy it in the real world.

And so these are
the two main inputs that go into
validation algorithms that we'll be talking
about in this class.

And what a validation
algorithm does is essentially takes that system
and specification and outputs some
information that

tells us whether the system is
satisfying the specification. So that information could
be something like a failure

analysis, so when
does the system not satisfy the specification.

It could be a formal
guarantee, so that would be something like
under a set of assumptions,

maybe sometimes we can prove
that a system will always satisfy a specification.

It could be an
explanation, so maybe we can explain why a system
doesn't satisfy a specification, or why it makes a
particular decision.

All the way to when we
deploy the system at runtime, we could kind of deploy it with
some online validation that

allows us to continue checking
if our system is operating as intended, when it's
out in the real world.

And so we're actually
going to discuss algorithms from all of these
different categories throughout the quarter.

And what I want to say here
is just that there's not really one single
algorithm that's going to do it all for us.

So there's not one
algorithm that we could just run it on our system, see
that the results pass,

and then confidently deploy
our system in the real world. And instead we
really need to apply algorithms for all
of these categories

to build a safety case. So you might be wondering why
there's these cheese looking things on this slide.

Essentially the idea
here is something called the Swiss cheese model. So maybe some of you have
heard of this before.

If you haven't, I'll give you a
quick 30-second overview of it. But the idea is basically
just that all of these methods

have different limitations
or holes in them, just like the slices of Swiss cheese.

But ideally, the limitations
that these algorithms have, maybe the limitations
of one algorithm don't line up with
the limitations

of another algorithm. As you can imagine, if
we stack enough of them together, just
like we're stacking

the slices of Swiss
cheese, then ideally we won't be able to see
through any of the holes. And so we'll be able
to catch everything

that other algorithms miss. And so the key idea here
is just that there's really

no silver bullet in
safety validation. And instead, we need to build a
safety case for these systems.

So like I said in
this class we're going to talk about
algorithms that fit into all of those categories of methods.

And so this course is
a really good place to start to give
you that toolbox to be able to validate the
systems that you design

before you deploy
them in the world.  So hopefully that gets you
excited to take this course.

Let me just talk for a
second about the plan for the rest of this lecture. So the course staff will
introduce themselves.

Then I'm going to do my
best, if I haven't already, to convince you that safety
validation is important.

We'll talk about the
validation framework that we're going to use
throughout this course.

So I'll introduce myself first. Here's just a timeline of
my academic journey so far.

So I did my undergrad
at Washington University in St. Louis in electrical
and systems engineering.

And during my time there, I
got to do some really cool internships, but one that's a
major highlight and particularly

relevant here was at
MIT Lincoln Laboratory. And that's actually
where I first met Mykel.

And also it was where I got
to work on a system called ACAS X. And essentially
what it does is collision

avoidance for aircraft. So this was my
first introduction to intelligent decision-making
systems that operate

in safety-critical settings. And so really it's what set
me down the path for my PhD.

So after I came
here to Stanford, I'd heard how great Mykel was. So I was really hoping
he'd let me in his lab.

And he did. And so for the next
five or so years, I worked on the
design and validation

of safety-critical
decision-making systems. And specifically, my PhD thesis
was focused on safe machine

learning-based perception. So it's like that
video that I'm showing there that would be an
example of a perception system

we might work on, where we
basically have a camera that's mounted on an
aircraft, that's trying

to detect other
aircraft in the sky to avoid colliding with them.

So then I got my PhD
in 2023, and I've stuck around as a postdoc
for the last year or so.

And a large portion of
my time as a postdoc was spent actually working on
the textbook for this course. So I've been doing a broad
survey of the validation

algorithms that are out
there, and I'm really excited to share them with you.

OK, so some fun stuff. I used to collect bouncy balls. I have jars of them
at my dad's house.

I never got my wisdom teeth,
so that doesn't mean-- it's not that I
never got them out. I just like never
got them, period.

They just never
formed in my mouth. I was born in the same hospital
as LeBron James and Steph Curry.

If you're not a basketball fan,
LeBron James and Steph Curry are two of the best basketball
players to ever live.

I did not get whatever
was in that hospital. I'm not the best basketball
player by any means. And actually to
really contrast that,

I didn't even learn to
ride a bike until I was 23. So if there's any
of you out there that still haven't
learned to ride a bike,

there's still hope for you. No worries. [LAUGHTER] I actually learned when I came
to Stanford, because there was just no other way that I was
going to be able to get around

this giant campus. But then I guess the
contrast that again with some athletic ability, I
used to jump rope competitively.

And I was part of Stanford
jump rope also for a few years while I was here.

And that's a picture of me at
Yosemite on our lab retreat last year jump roping.
All right, I'll let Mykel--  All right.
My name is Mykel Kochenderfer. I see a lot of familiar faces. Really happy to see you again.

And I'll be having office
hours by appointment, so feel free to send me a note.

I'm looking forward to
getting to know many of you. All of you, actually. So I came to Stanford
originally as an undergrad

and stayed for a coterm,
then went to the University of Edinburgh for the PhD.

I went to MIT
Lincoln Laboratory, which is a fantastic place to
work and make lifelong friends.

And then I stayed
there for seven years working on ACAS X and airspace
modeling and other areas.

And then I had the privilege
of coming back here in 2013 and starting the Stanford
Intelligent Systems

Laboratory or SISL. We've enjoyed collaborating with
a number of different research

sponsors, both
government and industry.

So, I'm a Swiftie. And you probably know that
if you took 228 with me.

I guess we're talking
about wisdom teeth now. So I got five of them. And I was a little loopy
after getting them extracted.

I like taking students
on overseas adventures. In the past couple of
summers we've gone to India.

This summer I'm taking a group
of 15 undergrads to Argentina.

It's not too late to apply. I have had zero bike
accidents at Stanford.

Owed, I think
primarily to the fact, that I treat it as a POMDP with
some heavy collision penalties.

[LAUGHTER] I'm a third-generation pilot. And yeah, really happy to
be a part of this course.

And also looking forward to
your feedback on the textbook and your feedback on
this course as well.

We hope to offer it every
year during winter quarter. OK, so that's
course staff intros.

Now I'm going to try to convince
you that safety validation is important.

So there was this teacher
that told students that they could bring in a 3 x
5 cheat sheet for their test.

But he didn't specify that
he meant 3 x 5 inches. So one student took the
liberty to then bring

in a 3 x 5 foot cheat
sheet for their test. And so this is an example
of a misspecified objective.

So I'll just say robots
and maybe some students will do exactly what
we tell them to do.

And we need to give
them good instructions. And there's actually a
name for this phenomenon,

and that's called the
alignment problem. And there's three
main things that can
cause the alignment problem. One is an imperfect objective. One is an imperfect model.

And then the last one is
imperfect optimization. So I'll go through these.

So what we just saw,
the cheat sheet thing, that's an example of
an imperfect objective. So the teacher's objective was
to have students bring in a 3 x

5 inch cheat sheet
for their test. But he kind of misspecified
that, and he just said 3 x 5.

So that was too ambiguous. And students could
interpret that how they wanted, and so one
student then brought in a 3 x

5 foot cheat sheet. Here's another
really famous example

of an imperfect objective. So the idea here is we
had some researchers that were trying to train an agent
to play this boat racing game,

and they wanted to essentially
train an agent that would be able to win the race.

And the way the game
is scored is just by this score that depends
on how many various objects

or items you pick
up along the route. And the idea is that a high
score should win the race.

So here's what actually
ended up happening. [VIDEO PLAYBACK] Let's play this video.

OK, so this should probably
look a little bit weird to you. It definitely doesn't
look like a boat that's trying to win the race.

And it turns out what happened
is the boat figured out or the agent figured
out that basically, if it was able to crash into
things at the exact right time

and speed, it could enter
into this infinite loop where it just collected
those green turbo

things, which gave it a
really high score forever into the future. So that's one way to
maximize the score.

But that's not what we as
the designers of the system actually wanted it to do. So this is another example of
an imperfect objective where

we told it to
maximize the score, but our actual intent
was to win the race.

Here's another
interesting example, which I actually tried at home. So many of you may
use coding agents

to help you write code
that use LLMs to complete the code you're writing.

So this is actually
in my VS Code. I just went ahead and
typed in, calculate

women's salary, input a base. And then what you
see grayed out there is what it was telling me to
complete the function with.

So it was basically telling
me to take the base salary, multiply it by 0.77 and
give that to the women.

And then I tried the same thing
calculate men's salary, input a base, and it was basically
telling me to take the base,

multiply it by 1.1 and
give that to the men. Seems a little bit unfair to me.

And this is another example
of a misaligned objective. So typically, when we
train agents like this,

we're just training them
to complete the next token in a sentence or
in a block of code.

And there's nothing in that
objective that necessarily says it needs to create fair code.

So again, this is a
mismatch in objectives.

The alignment problem could also
be caused by an imperfect model. And so one interesting
example of this,

which we mentioned in the
intro chapter of the book, is this hedge fund called
Long-Term Capital Management.

So this hedge fund
was created in 1994. And when it first
came out, people

were really excited about it. It was supposed
to do super well. And at the beginning it
actually did do quite well.

So you can see this
light blue line here that shows the
performance of the S&P

500 over the next few years
of when the fund came out. That's just a good thing to
index performance of funds

against. And you can see that
this dark blue line shows that the fund was pretty
significantly beating the S&P

500 for the first few
years of its existence. But the problem was that
the creators of this fund

actually had an imperfect
model of the world, and that they failed to
account for extreme events.

And so then when
extreme events did occur, such as the economic
crisis in Asia and Russia

in 1997, 1998, the
value of the fund plummeted quite
drastically to the point

where it actually ended up
requiring a multi-billion dollar bailout by a number
of banks, and that

was to avoid essentially
a global economic crisis. And what's interesting
about this example

is that part of the reason the
fund was so highly regarded was because it was created
by some very highly

regarded economists, two of
whom actually won the Nobel Prize in 1997 for their work
on the Black-Scholes model.

And so, if you're
interested, there's actually an interesting
book out about this called When Genius Failed.

So that's an example
of an imperfect model. And then finally,
the alignment problem could also be caused by
an imperfect optimization.

So, for example, here maybe we
have our objective perfectly specified. We know the model of the world.

But we still need to
then train our agent to do what we want it to. And so here's what
I typically think

of with imperfect optimization. Maybe we have a reward up
in the right corner there.

And what we would
want an agent to do is essentially just navigate
its way to get this reward.

But depending on the
optimization algorithm we're using to train our agent
to do that, it might not always

end up doing that. So for example, if
we have an algorithm that struggles with
sparse rewards.

So, for example, maybe it just
explores the space all around, then if it never knows
that this reward is here, then it still might not learn
the policy that we want it to.

So those are three things
that can cause what

we call the alignment problem. If you're interested
in learning more about the alignment
problem, we highly

recommend checking
out this book here. But the reason that
we're essentially talking about it right now is
because the alignment problem

is really what motivates
the need for validation. And this is especially true for
complex systems that operate

in safety-critical settings. So these are all examples that
are mentioned in the book.

On the left is a
health care example where there was this radiation
machine that due to a software

glitch, every once in
a while, would just administer a lethal dose
of radiation to patients.

So obviously that's not good. Many of you have probably
heard about the Boeing 737 MAX

incident or multiple
incidents that resulted in quite a bit of loss of life.

And then you've probably
heard about autonomous vehicle accidents in the news. And just what's key here to note
is that when these systems don't

operate the way we
intended them to, so when there is
some of misalignment, those failures can result
in very, very catastrophic

outcomes. So loss of very expensive
property or loss of human life. And so it's really,
really crucial

that we do validation in these
safety-critical settings.

So are you convinced now? Many companies and
regulatory agencies are.

So, for example, throughout
my PhD, I did a lot of work in the aviation domain.

That domain is extremely
highly regulated, specifically in the United States by the
Federal Aviation Administration,

or FAA, and in Europe by the
European Aviation Safety Agency,

or EASA. And they basically specify
all sorts of guidelines that you need to
comply with in order

to deploy something
in the airspace. And so this is just
an example of one of those guidelines
that is famous, DO-178C.

And it basically
specifies what you need to do to deploy
software on airborne systems.

And these guidelines can be
quite complicated or quite difficult, and
require lots of effort

to comply with and show
that your system complies with to the point
where there's actually

even like full textbooks
written just about complying with these standards.

And then what's interesting
as of recent is now AI

and machine learning
are starting to become super popular. And we're thinking
about what would happen

if we were to put them on
these safety-critical systems, for example, like aircraft. And these regulatory
agencies are very much

thinking about that too. So both the FAA and
EASA have released roadmaps of how they see AI and
machine learning being deployed

on these systems. But I think there's still a
number of open problems in terms

of how we actually validate
these systems to be safe enough

to put on these very
safety-critical systems. So if you're
interested, I think this is a really interesting
area of research.

And hopefully this class will
give you some good foundations to understand how
to dive into it.

OK, switching domains
to autonomous driving. So that's another domain that
obviously cares quite a bit about safety.

So for example, Waymo
on their website, they have an entire section
just devoted to safety.

And they often release very
detailed safety reports of their cars.

Of course, gotta mention LLMs. So Anthropic, for example,
which is a large LLM provider.

One of their core
research principles is safety and scaling. And you may have heard
recently, a lot of people

are interested in red
teaming these LLMs, so trying to find
inputs or prompts that cause them to misbehave.

And I think this red
teaming is actually quite similar, at least
in concept and idea, to the falsification
that we're going

to talk about in this class. So hopefully this is also a
good place to start for that.

And these companies are hiring. So if anyone's
looking for a job, this should hopefully give
you some pretty good skills.

I just went on their websites. And if you search
safety, there's plenty of jobs that are
literally just devoted to safety.

But I think even if you're not
going into a position that's specifically focused
on safety, this

is a really valuable
set of skills to have. Because no matter what the
thing you deploy in the world after you design it, you want it
to do what you intended it to.

OK, are you convinced now? I hope so, because
we're going to move on.

[CHUCKLES] So now I'm going to jump into
introducing the validation

framework for this course. So we already
talked about how we structure validation problems.

So we have a system, we
have a specification, and then those go into
a validation algorithm.

The textbook that we'll be
using is structured in this way. So the second chapter is
all about how we actually

go about modeling the
system, which we'll talk about in the next lecture.

The third chapter is about
how we can specify formally the properties for the system.

And then the remaining chapters,
which is the meat of the book and the meat of this class
is the validation algorithms

that we'll get into. So just briefly
right now I'm going to describe each
of these components

just so you can get an idea
of how everything's set up. So I'll start with the system.

OK, so there's lots of different
ways to define a system. And you might define
systems differently depending on what class you're
in or what domain you're in.

In this class,
we're going to say a system consists of an agent,
an environment, and a sensor,

and they fit together like this. So essentially the
environment keeps track of state of the world
that's relevant to the problem

that we're interested in. The sensor then
observes that state

and gives us an
observation of that state. The observation then
gets passed to the agent,

which uses that observation
to select an action to take. And then given that
action, that environment

will transition to a new state. And then this
process just repeats.

And the way that we
more formally model each of these things is using
probability distributions.

And specifically,
we use something called a conditional
probability distribution, which we'll talk more about
in the second lecture.

But essentially,
the idea here is just that for the agent, for
example, given the observation

that it receives, it
has some probability of taking each action. So this represents
the probability

of taking action a given that
we received observation o. And we call this a policy.

Once the agent has
picked an action, it goes over to this thing we
call the transition model, which

essentially tells us, given
the current state we're in and the current
action that we take, what is the probability of
transitioning to state s prime.

And then that new state gets
observed by a sensor, which basically tells us,
given that we're

in state s, what is the
probability that we end up with observation o.

So I'm going to try
to make this concrete. I think throughout
the class, what I'm going to do my best
to keep running examples

going so that I can make
all these things concrete. And one running example we're
going to use quite a bit

is the inverted pendulum. So here's a picture of it. Essentially, the idea here
with an inverted pendulum,

if you've never seen it, so a
normal pendulum goes like this. Inverted pendulum is
flipped upside down.

And the goal is
basically to keep the pendulum balanced upright. And we can do that by applying
torques at the bottom of it.

And so we want to keep it
balanced completely vertical.

And so to represent the
state of the pendulum, we're going to say the state
is its angle from the vertical,

so this angle here. We'll call that theta. And then the other
component of the state

is its angular velocity, so how
fast that angle is changing. And we'll call that omega.

So that state will then go
into our observation model

for the inverted pendulum. We'll talk more about
what this distribution is in the next lecture.

But essentially it's a
multivariate Gaussian distribution that's
centered at the true state

with some covariance that
represents some amount of noise on the true state.

So then we can
sample an observation from this observation model,
and we get something like this.

So here we have the true
state of the pendulum which is like what's shown
in white and then the observation is that shadow
there that's in the dark gray.

And we'll call that theta
hat and omega hat that then gets passed to the agent.

In this case for the
inverted pendulum, the agent is deterministic,
meaning that it always takes the same action.

And so the way we represent that
as a probability distribution is just by saying that
with probability 1,

we take this action. And for all other actions, we
take them with probability 0.

For those of you
who are interested, this is just a
proportional controller. So we just multiply the
components of the state

by some values. And that tells us what torque
to apply to the pendulum. You don't have to worry about
knowing how to derive this

or how to come up with this. There's other classes
at Stanford for that. In this class, we're just
going to give you the equations

for all of these things. And then once we've
selected an action, it goes over to the environment.

And very similarly
for the pendulum, the environment
is deterministic. So with probability 1, we
transition to this new angle

and this new angular velocity. And then all other states
have 0 probability.

And then kind of same thing. There's other
classes at Stanford that tell you how to
derive these equations. You don't need to worry
about how to do that.

We'll always just
give them to you. Any questions on that?

Yep. So in this the model that I was
looking at a continuous time system since I see this
delta t in the [INAUDIBLE]

Yes, that's a great question. It does change things sometimes. In this class, we're
going to focus entirely
on discrete time systems. Good question.

So you'll notice if you've
checked out the textbook yet, the algorithms are
implemented in actual code.

So instead of
pseudocode in the book, we actually use real
code in a language called Julia, which
we'll be getting

familiar with
throughout the quarter. So this is a first
example of a code block.

What's really nice
about Julia is that it's very, very human readable. So instead of writing
in pseudocode,

we can just write the
algorithms in Julia, and they're basically
just as readable. So all that's really happening
in this code block here

is we're defining types for the
agent, environment, and sensor. And then we're just
saying that a system type consists of an agent,
an environment, and a sensor.

Then given this,
we can actually go about trying to implement
this loop that's going

on here as a function in code. So what we're
going to do here is we're going to
assume that we start

in some initial state like this. So that's input to our function. And then we go to the
next part of this loop

where we use our
sensor to produce an observation of that state. So for the pendulum, it's
like that noisy observation

I was talking about. That observation then gets
passed to the agent here,

and it uses that observation
to pick an action. In this case, it's
this torque here.

And then that action is
given to the environment, and we transition to a new
state we'll call s prime.

And then we just
return what happened so that we have that information.

So that's one time step. But you can imagine if you want
to keep going around this loop, we could continue to compute
this over a number of time steps

all the way to some
desired depth d. And we do this it
produces a trajectory.

And we call this process
a rollout of the system. So essentially, here's
another function

where it's called rollout. We take in our system
and some desired depth d.

And all that's going
on here is we're sampling a random initial state,
initializing our trajectory.

And then for each step
up to the depth d, we take one step of our system,
look at what was output,

just store that
in our trajectory, and then set our state
to be that new state. And then we just continue
to do this until depth d

and return the
trajectory that we get. So here's what that looks like
for the inverted pendulum.

So I'm going to show
a 20-step rollout, which ends up being
2 seconds long.

So here's what it looks like. So you see we're able
to balance the pendulum. And it's kind of nice
to see those videos just

to get a physical understanding
of what's going on. But in this class, we're
